verses.text: Now Solomon decided to build a temple for the name of the LORD, and a royal palace for himself.
verses.comment: Verse parallels 1 Kings 5:5; 'temple for the name of the LORD' reflects Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: Solomon assigned seventy thousand men to bear burdens, eighty thousand to quarry stone in the hill country, and three thousand six hundred overseers to manage them.
verses.comment: Numbers of workers match the Hebrew; 'overseers' translated from 'capable men over them.'

verses.text: And Solomon sent this message to Huram king of Tyre: 'As you did for my father David and sent him cedars to build a house for him to live in, so do for me.
verses.comment: 'Huram'—Hebrew alternately 'Hiram'; text preserves original personal names.

verses.text: 'See, I am about to build a house for the name of the LORD my God, dedicating it to him, to burn fragrant incense before him, to set out the showbread continually, and for burnt offerings morning and evening, on Sabbaths, new moons, and the appointed feasts of the LORD our God, as it is required forever for Israel.'
verses.comment: 'Showbread' literal from Hebrew 'bread of the arrangement.'

verses.text: 'The house that I am going to build will be great, for our God is greater than all gods.'
verses.comment: 'Greater than all gods' reflects ancient context; does not imply acknowledgment of other gods as real.

verses.text: 'But who is able to build him a house, since heaven, even the highest heaven, cannot contain him? Who am I to build him a house, except as a place to burn offerings before him?'
verses.comment: 'Heaven, even the highest heaven'—literal rendering of Hebrew superlative.

verses.text: 'So now send me a man skilled to work in gold, silver, bronze, iron, purple, crimson, and blue fabrics, and trained in engraving, to join with the skilled men who are with me in Judah and Jerusalem, whom David my father provided.'
verses.comment: Lists skills and materials in Hebrew order; 'trained in engraving'—literal.

verses.text: 'Also send me cedar, cypress, and algum logs from Lebanon, for I know your servants are skilled in cutting timber in Lebanon. My servants will be with your servants.'
verses.comment: 'Algum' (or 'almug') trees—transliterated from Hebrew; exact species uncertain.

verses.text: 'To prepare timber in abundance for me, for the house I am about to build will be great and wonderful.'
verses.comment: 'Great and wonderful'—literal to Hebrew 'great and marvelous.'

verses.text: 'Behold, I will give your servants, the cutters who cut the timber, twenty thousand cors of crushed wheat, twenty thousand cors of barley, twenty thousand baths of wine, and twenty thousand baths of oil.'
verses.comment: 'Cor' and 'bath' are ancient measures: one cor ≈ 220 liters; one bath ≈ 22 liters.

verses.text: Then Huram king of Tyre answered in a letter that he sent to Solomon: 'Because the LORD loves his people, he has made you king over them.'
verses.comment: Retains third person address as in Hebrew and ancient custom.

verses.text: Huram added, 'Blessed be the LORD, the God of Israel, who made heaven and earth, who has given King David a wise son, endowed with discretion and understanding, who will build a house for the LORD and a royal palace for himself.'
verses.comment: 'Blessed be the LORD' reflects Hebrew blessing formula; adds 'who made heaven and earth'; parallels Psalm 124:8.

verses.text: 'Now I am sending a skilled man, who has understanding, Huram-abi,
verses.comment: 'Huram-abi' transliterated as in Hebrew manuscripts; some MT read as single word.

verses.text: the son of a woman of the daughters of Dan, and his father was a man of Tyre. He is skilled to work in gold, silver, bronze, iron, stone, wood, purple, blue, fine linen, and crimson fabrics, and in engraving any kind of design, and to work with your craftsmen and with the craftsmen of my lord David your father.'
verses.comment: 'Son of a woman of the daughters of Dan' follows MT; 1 Kings reads 'Naphtali.'

verses.text: 'Now then, let my lord send to his servants the wheat, barley, oil, and wine, as promised.'
verses.comment: 'As promised' is implied from context, matching Hebrew flow.

verses.text: 'And we will cut wood from Lebanon, as much as you need, and bring it to you as rafts by sea to Joppa; and you will carry it up to Jerusalem.'
verses.comment: 'Joppa' is the historical port for Jerusalem timber shipments.

verses.text: Then Solomon counted all the foreigners who were in the land of Israel, after the census that David his father had taken, and they were found to be one hundred fifty-three thousand six hundred.
verses.comment: Numbers reflect literal Hebrew for the workforce census.

verses.text: He assigned seventy thousand of them to carry burdens, eighty thousand to quarry stone in the hill country, and three thousand six hundred overseers to make the people work.
verses.comment: 'Burdens' and 'quarry stone' literal to Hebrew; matches earlier verse 2.
